title-group.article-title: Study on the possibility of increasing the maximum allowable stresses in fibre-reinforced plastics

article-meta.aff: 1Chalmers University of Technology, Department of Shipping and Marine Technology, Gothenburg, Sweden
2SP Technical Research Institute of Sweden, Department of Building Technology and Mechanics, Borås, Sweden

author-notes.corresp: LF Sánchez-Heres, Shipping and Marine Technology, Chalmers University of Technology, SE – 412 96 Gothenburg, Sweden. Email: luis.sanchez@chalmers.se

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This article presents the results of a study aimed at investigating the possibility of increasing the maximum allowable stresses in fibre-reinforced plastics compared to current practice. The study consisted of a comparison between the maximum allowable stresses of a group of cross-ply laminates, determined by deterministic analyses with safety and model factors as stated in design rules, and their probabilistic responses estimated with a fracture mechanics based model that accounted for material degradation. The results suggest that for the studied cases, the maximum allowable stresses do not provide the desired reliability; thus, their increase cannot be motivated. More importantly, the investigation shows that a better understanding of the effects of matrix cracks, and therefore, the maximum allowable crack density in a composite laminate, would lead to better and safer composite structures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fibre-reinforced plastics (FRPs) have been used in the transport industry for more than four decades now. Because of international regulations, rising fuel prices and environmental concerns there is now a strong worldwide interest on reducing fuel consumption. One way of accomplishing this is by reducing the weight of the structure by manufacturing more structural components with FRPs. The reduction in weight translates into a reduction in fuel consumption or an increase in the usability of the vehicle. For example, in the case of the maritime industry, large components of a ship structure manufactured with FRPs could substantially reduce the vessel’s deadweight, improving its payload capacity. While this approach has been proven to be technically feasible and economically sound in joint industry projects,1 there is still much to be gained if the material utilization as defined by design rules2,3 could be increased.

The objective of this study was to investigate the possibility of increasing the utilization of FRPs compared to the limits stated in design rules for marine structures. Such an increase would hopefully lead to reductions in cost and weight for FRP structures. To find out if such possibility exists, the maximum allowable stresses of a group of cross-ply FRP laminates, as defined by design rules, were evaluated in order to determine quantitatively and qualitatively, if they gave the target reliability level. If the given reliability level was higher than the desired one, an increase of the maximum allowable stresses could be motivated.

To perform a broad and accurate evaluation of the reliability given by the maximum allowable stresses, the results of a set of probabilistic material response analyses that included the initiation, progression and effects of degradation due to loading, as well as laminate failure, were used as benchmarks for the evaluation.

sec.title: Probabilistic analyses
sec.p: Probabilistic analyses of composite laminate failure are not uncommon in the literature. Nakayasu and Maekawa4 calculated and compared several stochastic failure envelopes for a unidirectional laminate. Jeong and Shenoi5,6 estimated the probabilistic strength distribution of composite laminates with a variety of stacking sequences subjected to an out-of-plane load. Nader et al.7 performed a probabilistic failure analysis of a cross-ply laminate subjected to tension. In all of these investigations the ultimate limit state (ULS) was considered to be the first ply failure. This event was predicted with a variety of failure criteria that do not distinguish between the different ply failure modes, fibre fracture and matrix cracking among others. The degradation of the material before reaching the ULS was not considered in any of these analyses. Matrix cracking and delamination commonly occur before fibre fracture and lead to a redistribution of stresses in the laminate. If these events are not taken into account in the material response model, the predicted laminate strength will be overestimated.

Mahadevan et al.,8 Liu and Mahadevan9 and Mahadevan and Liu10 presented a methodology for estimating the probability of failure of an FRP laminate that incorporated material degradation. Fibre fracture, matrix cracking and delamination were recognized as distinct failure modes. The methodology consisted on evaluating the laminate as a system, and each ply failure mode as a component with a particular failure probability. The failure mode with the highest probability of occurrence was selected and the ply stiffness was modified to reflect the type of damage. When fibre fracture was predicted to take place, all the fibre-dominated stiffness terms of that ply (E1, G12 and G13) where reduced to zero. In a similar fashion, matrix cracking and delamination reduced the other stiffness terms. Sánchez et al.11 presented a probabilistic analysis of a model that incorporated material degradation due to matrix cracking. When matrix cracking was predicted, the transverse and shear stiffness of the damaged ply (E2 and G12) where multiplied by a degradation factor, in contrast with more conservative approaches where the stiffness terms are reduced nearly to zero.

The incorporation of laminate stiffness degradation due to matrix cracking is indeed a step forward to obtaining more accurate analyses, although how much more accurate is debatable. The effect of matrix cracking in the redistribution of stresses is very much dependent on a variety of factors such as: fibre and matrix type, stacking sequence and ply thickness for example. One big consideration in these analyses8–11 is that ply matrix cracking is considered to be a discrete fully developed event. Matrix cracking occurs only once in each ply and then the ply stiffness is fully or partially degraded; in contrast, several investigations12,13 have concluded that matrix cracking is a progressive event; for instance, Talreja14 presented an analysis where a degradation method8–10 was proven to give very conservative results. The degradation factors used in Sánchez et al.11 need experimental testing to be determined and are valid only for the evaluated laminate. Because of all these reasons, a material response model incorporating degradation due to progressive matrix cracking will be used in the probabilistic analyses.

sec.title: Progressive matrix cracking models
sec.p: Numerous progressive matrix cracking models have been presented in the literature. Several of them use the so-called shear-lag models to calculate the displacement and stress fields in cracked plies. Highsmith and Reifsnider15 documented the stiffness degradation, due to the accumulation of matrix cracks, of a group of cross-ply glass/epoxy laminates. The experimental measurements were later compared against predictions made with a shear-lag model. Laws and Dvorak16 presented a model for predicting the progressive formation of matrix cracks in cross-ply laminates, and their effects, by means of a shear-lag model and a fracture mechanics criterion. Wang et al.17,18 presented an approach that did not use a shear-lag model. They predicted the crack density in cross-ply laminates through a stochastic model. Flaw separations and sizes were randomly generated following probability distributions that were calibrated with experimental observations, then, a fracture mechanics criterion was used to predict the order at which matrix cracks would occur. Lee and Daniel19 presented a simple shear-lag model with closed form solutions for the stress distributions, degraded stiffness and matrix crack density for cross-ply laminates. Jen and Sun20 predicted the matrix cracking and delamination of a group of cross-ply laminates. They assumed even crack spacing and utilized a finite element analysis to calculate the normal stress around a transverse matrix crack, then the maximum stress criterion coupled to a Weibull size effect law was used to predict matrix cracking. Fracture mechanics was employed to predict delamination onset and growth. Berthelot and Le Corre21 calculated the matrix crack development in cross-ply laminates with a shear-lag model, the maximum strength criterion for predicting the formation of matrix cracks, and an analytical delamination analysis. The analyzed specimens were divided into elements along the length and their transverse strength was randomly sampled following a pseudo normal distribution. Hashin22,23 developed a variational method to estimate the progressive loss of stiffness as well as the stress fields in cross-ply laminates due to the formation of matrix cracks. Nairn,24–27 Nairn and Hu,28,29 and Liu and Nairn30 extended Hashin’s approach to account for residual stresses and generalized it for other layups ([S/90°]S and [90°/S]S). Their analyses utilized the variational method along with a fracture mechanics criterion to calculate matrix crack density vs. laminate stress curves. Subsequently, Nairn et al.31 thoroughly demonstrated the validity and higher accuracy oftheir method over shear-lag models and strength criteria for the prediction of progressive transversematrix cracking in [S/90°]S and [90°/S]S laminates. More recently, several methods have been proposed to predict the formation and propagation of matrix cracks in multidirectional laminates,32–35 however, due to their complexity, the use of these methods for probabilistic analyses is unpractical.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: The investigation was divided into three parts. First, the maximum allowable stresses of four cross-ply laminate layups were calculated with a commonly used deterministic linear elastic material response analysis with partial safety and model factors, following the procedure stated in a design standard for composite components.3 Second, a probabilistic variational fracture mechanics analysis, as developed by Nairn and colleagues,24–27,29–31 was used to predict the probabilistic initiation, accumulation and effects of matrix cracks, as well the ULS for each one of the layups. Additionally, a sensitivity analysis was performed to gain further insight into the behaviour of the probabilistic model. Last, a comparison was made between the maximum allowable stresses and the probabilistic failure and degradation estimations. With the comparison, conclusions were drawn on the level of reliability given by the maximum allowable stresses and the possibility of increasing the material utilization. For simplification, from this point onwards, the deterministic linear elastic material response analysis with safety and model factors, and the probabilistic variational fracture mechanics analysis, will be referred to as the ‘deterministic analysis’ and the ‘probabilistic analysis’, respectively.

sec.title: Study cases
sec.p:
Four cross-ply laminates made out of AS4/3501-6 carbon/epoxy prepreg were studied. This material is not commonly used in marine structures; however, it is covered by the standard and was selected for this investigation due to the large amount of published experimental data. The layups of each one of the cross-ply laminates were [0/90]S, [0/902]S, [0/904]S and [02/902]S. The analyses consider the laminates to be subjected to a unidirectional displacement-controlled tension load. The material data and crack density measurements were taken from the work presented by Nairn27 and Liu and Nairn,30 the only exception being the longitudinal tensile failure strain, which was assigned the expected value presented by Soden et al.36 Table 1 presents the material data used in this investigation. The expectancy values were used in the deterministic analyses, while the rest of the information was used in the probabilistic analyses. A discussion regarding the chosen probability distributions and coefficients of variation (COV) for the input variables is presented in the setup of probabilistic analyses section. No correlations between the input variables were considered. Table 1.
Material properties of an AS4/3501-6 carbon/epoxy ply
Property Expectancy COV Prob. Distribution
Longitudinal modulus, E1 (GPa) 130 5% Normal
Transverse modulus, E2 (GPa) 9.7 5% Normal
In-plane shear modulus, G12 (GPa) 5 5% Normal
Out-of-plane shear modulus, G23 (GPa) 3.6 5% Normal
In-plane Poisson’s ratio, ν12 0.3 5% Normal
Out-of-plane Poisson’s ratio, ν23 0.5 5% Normal
Long. thermal expansion coefficient, α1 (10−6/℃) –0.09 – –
Trans. thermal expansion coefficient, α2 (10−6/℃) 28.8 – –
Microcracking fracture toughness, Gmc (J/m2) 220 5% Weibull/Normal
Ambient - stress free temperature, T (℃) –95 5% Normal
Ultimate longitudinal tensile strain, ɛu1T (%) 1.38 10% Weibull/Normal
Characteristic ultimate long. tensile straina, ɛu1T* (%) 0.910 – –
Ply thickness, tply (mm) 0.155 5% Normal
Average crack formation interval/average crack spacing ratio, f 1.05 – –
a
Characteristic strength calculated assuming 10 samples.

sec.title: Deterministic analyses
sec.p: In the deterministic analysis, the linear elastic response of the cross-ply laminates was calculated with classical lamination theory,37 and the ultimate limit state of the laminates was considered to be fibre fracture predicted with the maximum strain criterion.37

The values of the partial safety and model factors for each cross-ply laminate are shown in Table 2, and were determined as stated in the offshore standard for composite components of the classification society Det Norske Veritas.3 The combined load and resistance safety factor that accounts for variability was selected considering the following: fibre fracture to be brittle and the ULS fibre strength to have a COV of 10%, the load a COV of 0%, and the target safety class to be ‘normal’. A normal safety class means that the probability of failure (Pf) or in other words the probability of reaching the ULS, should be 10−5. The non-degraded (Eo) and fully degraded (Edeg) elastic moduli of the cross-ply laminates used in the calculations of the resistance model factors were determined with classical lamination theory. For Edeg the transverse and in-plane shear ply stiffness (E2 and G12), as well as the in-plane Poisson’s ratio (ν12) were set to 1% of their original value. The load model factors were set to 1 (unity) because in the standard, classical lamination theory is considered to give a good prediction of the stresses in the laminates under the loading condition of our study cases. Table 2.
Partial safety and model factors and maximum allowable stresses
Factor/Stress [0/90]S [0/902]S [0/904]S [02/902]S
Combined load and resistance safety factor, γFM 1.40 1.40 1.40 1.40
Load model factor, γSd 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00
Resistance model factor, γRd = Eo/Edeg 1.08 1.15 1.32 1.08
Maximum allowable stress, σmax (MPa) 423 283 170 423

The maximum allowable strain in the 0° plies (ɛmax) was calculated by reducing the characteristic tensile strain in the fibre direction (ɛu1T*), presented in Table 1, with the partial safety and model factors: (1)ɛmax=ɛu1T*γFM·γSd·γRd

The only element from the standard that was not included in these analyses was the time dependency of the ply’s characteristic strength due to creep. The reason for this simplification being that, in this study, the long-term response and strain-rate effects of the laminates were not considered. Considering that the cross-ply laminates were symmetric, subjected to a unidirectional displacement controlled tensile load, and accounting for the residual thermal strains with the apparent laminate thermal expansion coefficient (αx), the maximum allowable laminate stresses(σmax) presented in Table 2, were calculated as follows: (2)σmax=E0(ɛmax-(αx-α1)T)

sec.title: Variational fracture mechanics analysis
sec.p:
The analysis used in the probabilistic calculation was a variational fracture mechanics analysis, following the developments by Nairn and colleagues.24–27,29–31 The analysis was used to predict the formation, accumulation and effects of matrix cracks in the 90° plies of the cross-ply laminates. For ease of comparison with the references, in this section we follow the nomenclature used by Nairn.26 The subscripts 1 and 2, and the superscripts (1) and (2), indicate terms corresponding to the 90° and 0° plies respectively as shown in Figure 1, while the superscript 0 denotes the stress of an undamaged laminate. The studied laminates were considered to be in a plane stress condition and to be subjected to a uniaxial laminate stress σX; therefore, the stress in the un-cracked 90° ply can be expressed as (3)σxx,10=km,1σX+kth,1T where km,1 and kth,1 are the mechanical and thermal stiffness constants of the 90° ply, both of them calculated through a one-dimensional stress analysis, as presented by Nairn and Hu.29 Micro cracks tend to form at roughly regular intervals in cross-ply laminates; therefore, new matrix cracks tend to form in the middle of the intervals. Such behaviour is depicted in Figure 1. Taking advantage of this behaviour, the average crack density of a cross-ply laminate can be predicted by only analysing a unit cell of laminate bounded by two cracks, as shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Lateral view of a [0/90n]S laminate before (A) and after (B) the formation of a matrix crack.

Experimental observations13,38 showed that the formation of a matrix crack is, for all but some very particular layups, an instant formation of a finite amount of new fracture area. Congruently with these observations the formation of a crack was predicted when the energy release rate due to the formation of such a crack (Gm), was equal to the critical energy release rate for microcracking, referred to in this text as the microcracking fracture toughness (Gmc). The energy release rate at the middle between two cracks, applicable to [0m/90n]S cross-ply laminates subjected to a displacement control tensile loading was found by Nairn26 as: (4)Gm=(σxx,10)2C3t1(2EAL(fρ/2)E0XL(fρ/2) -EAL(fρ)E0XL(fρ)) where (5)E0EAL(fρ)=1+Exx,12C3XL(fρ)E0(1+λ)fρandρ=12t1D=at1

C3 and λ are laminate constants and XL(ρ) is the lower bound of the excess energy function obtained from the variational analysis, all of them are defined by Liu and Nairn.30 The crack interval length a and the 90° ply thickness t1 are defined in Figure 1. D is the average crack density, ρ the axial ratio of the average crack interval, and EAL(ρ) is the lower bound effective axial modulus of the cracked laminate with exactly periodic microcrack intervals of aspect ratio ρ. At low crack densities the value of Gm, as defined by equation (4), is independent of the crack spacing; however, at high crack densities the value of Gm decreases, as the crack interval grows smaller. This means that cracks will tend to form in intervals with spacings higher than the average one. To account for this effect, and to obtain the correct high crack densities, the adjustable parameter f is introduced, see Liu and Nairn30 for details. With equations (3) and (4), and considering that a matrix crack occurs when Gmc = Gm, one is able to obtain an expression relating the laminate stress σX and the average crack density D: (6)σX=1km,1(GmcC3t1Y(D)-kth,1T) where (7)Y(D)=2EAL(fρ/2)E0XL(fρ/2)-EAL(fρ)E0XL(fρ)

Utilizing equation(6) we were able to predict the average crack density vs. stress curves for the cross-ply laminates. Figure 2 shows the fit of the predictions against experimental data using the material properties shown in Table 1. The maximum strain criterion was used to determine the ULS of the laminate. The fit of the predicted curves against the experimental data can be drastically improved by slightly varying the values of Gmc and T, such variations being well within the natural variability of these properties. Figure 2.
Comparison of experimental measurements and calculated average crack density vs. laminate stress curves.

sec.title: Measurements of interest
sec.p:
In this investigation five measurements at four points in the average crack density vs. laminate stress curve, were considered to be of interest, as shown in Figure 3,Point 1
Stress at matrix cracking onset (D = 0.01 cracks/mm). Figure 3.
Measurements of interest in the average crack density vs. laminate stress curve. Point 2
Stress at a very high crack density (D = 1 crack/mm).Point 3
Crack density at the maximum allowable stress (σX = σmax).Point 4
Stress at the ULS (ɛ0 = ɛu1T).Point 4
Crack density at the ULS.

These measurements were selected so that the maximum allowable stresses can be compared not only against the probabilistic failure predictions of the laminate, but also to its probabilistic state of degradation. The levels of crack density, referred to in this text as ‘very high’, ‘high’ or ‘low’ are based solely on qualitative considerations.

sec.title: Sensitivity analyses
sec.p: A sensitivity analysis was performed to identify which were the stochastic input variables that contributed the most to the variation of the output, in this case the measurements of interest, and to answer as well if the importance of the stochastic input variables was dependent on the laminate layup and the type of distribution for Gmc and ɛu1T.

A variance-based method was used for the sensitivity analysis. Considering a model Y = f(X), where Y is the output and X a vector of n independent stochastic input variables, the variance-based methods are used to estimate the contributions of each one of the stochastic input variables Xi to the unconditional variance of the output V(Y). When the inputs are independent, the output variance can be decomposed into terms of increasing dimensionality (8)V(Y)=∑iVi+∑i<jVij+∑i<j<kVijk+… where Vi is the variance that would be removed from the output if the true value of the input variable Xi was known. This measure is sometimes called the ‘main effect’ or the ‘first-order effect’. Vij is the effect that the interactions of Xi and Xj have on the output variance, known as the ‘second-order effect’. Similarly Vijk is known as the ‘third-order effect’ and so on with the subsequent terms. The total contribution of an input variable Xi to the output variance can be expressed as the summation of the first and higher order effects related to that variable, the division of this summation by the unconditional output variance gives us the total sensitivity index STi of the model to the input variable Xi (9)STi=Vi+Vij+Vijk+…V(Y)

The total sensitivity indexes can then be used to rank the stochastic input variables by importance. The great advantage of these indexes is that the interactions between the input variables are considered; therefore, this method is ideal for non-linear models such as ours.39

The total sensitivity indexes were calculated for each measurement, layup and distribution type. The calculation of indexes was performed with the SIMLAB software40 using the extended Fourier amplitude sensitivity test method,41 a model independent method that relies solely on the results of model evaluations. For each combination of layup and distribution type, 8000 model evaluations were performed; however, some of the measurements of interest do not occur in every evaluation, for example, the ULS might be reached before an average crack density of 1 crack/mm is attained.

Figure 4 presents the calculated total sensitivity indexes, where the size and shade of the bubbles reflect their magnitude. This type of graph was used in order to identify trends and importance more easily. The results obtained when Gmc and ɛu1T had a Weibull or a normal distribution are labelled as ‘WBL’ and ‘NORM’ respectively. A figure for the crack density at the ULS (point 4) was produced, but it is not included in this report since it is very similar to Figure 4(d). Figure 4.
Total sensitivity indexes for the measurements of interest.

In general, there is not much dependence on whether the Gmc and ɛu1T have normal or Weibull distributions. The least important variables for all of the layups are the shear stiffness and Poisson’s ratios of the ply. Figure 4a clearly shows that the most important of the variables for the stress at matrix cracking onset are t90°ply, E1, E2, Gmc and T. The stiffness of the plies loses importance as the number of 90° plies increase, while Gmc, t90°ply and T gains importance. Figure 4(b) shows a very strong dependence of the stress at high crack density on the type of layup evaluated. The total sensitivity indexes for the [0/904]S layup are particularly interesting since only E1 is considered to contribute to the variability of this measurement. This, as will be shown further on, is because the [0/904]S layup is very unlikely to reach an average crack density of 1 crack/mm, therefore, the number of model evaluations in the sensitivity analysis that presented such high crack density, were probably not enough to determine the contribution to the variation of the other input variables. Other insights from the sensitivity analysis are mentioned in the discussion section.

sec.title: Setup of the probabilistic analyses
sec.p: The probabilistic analyses for each layup consisted of two Monte Carlo simulations. The deterministic analyses were set to guarantee a Pf of the laminate of 10−5. Hence, the cumulative distribution functions calculated through the Monte Carlo simulations should be accurate at such low probabilities. The rule of thumb for Monte Carlo simulations, stating that the number of simulations should be of an order of magnitude 100/Pf42 was followed in order to guarantee accuracy at that probability; therefore, 107 simulations were performed with random sampled input variables in every Monte Carlo simulation. Of all the measurements of interest, only the ones in point 4, related to the ULS, occur in every single simulation. As mentioned in the sensitivity analyses section,this behaviour is due to the variation of the stochastic input variables, certain combinations lead to simulations where the cross-ply laminates are predicted to fail before they reach the maximum allowed stress, start cracking or, if physically possible, achieve a crack density of 1 crack/mm. Consequently, because of the smaller number of observations, the cumulative distribution functions of the measurements at points 1, 2s and 3, for some of the layups, have a reduced accuracy at low probabilities.

The expected values, COV and distributions used are presented in Table 1. In all of the Monte Carlo simulations all the stochastic input variables, except Gmc and ɛu1T, had a normal distribution following current practice43 and what one would expect considering the centre limit theorem. For each laminate layup the first Monte Carlo simulation used a Weibull distribution for the Gmc and ɛu1T, while the second, used a normal distribution instead. For the ɛu1T both types of distributions are used in the literature,43,44 while to the authors’ knowledge, for Gmc only a Weibull distribution has been used.27 The true type of distribution for the ɛu1T is a very uncertain issue. Several models have been developed to describe the statistical nature of the fracture process in fibre-reinforced composites.45 After reviewing the developed theories, it seems reasonable to assume that a Weibull and a normal distribution bound the real distribution of ɛu1T. In this investigation both distributions were used for Gmc and ɛu1T to consider the effects that this lack of knowledge has on the interpretation of the results. The COV used for the stochastic input variables were considered to be reasonable considering conservative engineering judgment and published values.43,46 A significant simplification was that no correlation between the stochastic input variables was considered.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
With the purpose of simplifying the comparison between the results of the probabilistic and deterministic analyses, the results of the former are presented with boxplots. Figure 5 shows the properties given to the boxplots used to present the probabilistic distributions of the measurements of interest. In the lower boxplot, the left and right whiskers indicate the values where the measurement has a probability of occurrence equal or less than 10−5 and 0.999 respectively. The sides of the box point to the upper and lower quartiles (0.25 and 0.75) of the distribution and the white circle marks the median (0.5). The upper boxplot has an additional slight modification. The value marked by the left whisker is marked with a cross and the 95% confidence interval of this value with two vertical lines. This type of boxplot is only utilized for the measurement of the stress at the ULS. Dashed and solid whiskers are used to differentiate the results obtained from the two different types of Monte Carlo simulations defined by the types of distributions used for the stochastic input variables: all inputs Normal distributed, or all Normal except Weibull distributed Gmc and ɛu1T. Figure 5.
Explanation of the quantiles represented through the boxplots.

Figure 6 shows the comparison of the results of the deterministic and probabilistic analyses in an average crack density vs. laminate stress plot for each one of the layups. The vertical dashed-dot line indicates the maximum allowable stress given by the deterministic analysis, and the solid line curves are the deterministic calculations of the variational fracture mechanics analysis as presented in Figure 2. The location of the boxplots matches the points where the measurements were made, as shown in Figure 3. The black horizontal boxplots indicate the measured stresses, while the grey vertical ones indicate measured crack densities. Figure 6.
Comparison between the probabilistic and deterministic analyses performed on the study cases.

sec.title: Point 1. Stress at matrix cracking onset (D = 0.01 cracks/mm)
sec.p: The median and scatter of the applied stress at matrix cracking onset is different in each one of the cross-ply laminates. Both, median and scatter decrease as the number of 90° plies are increased. One can appreciate that for the [0/90]S layup matrix cracking may start at the maximum allowed stress, while for the other layups matrix cracking is very likely to have already started at that stress. Overall there seems to be a small difference between the values predicted with Weibull and normal distributions.

sec.title: Point 2. Stress at a very high crack density (D = 1 crack/mm)
sec.p: Very high crack density at the maximum allowed stress is very unlikely to occur for the [0/90]S laminate, while apparently impossible for the other laminates. Never the less, at higher stresses the [0/90]S and [0/902]S laminates are very likely to have such high crack densities before their ULS. The [02/902]S laminates are predicted to present very rarely such high crack density, in Figure 6 one can notice that median of this measurement is at a higher stress than the median of the stress at the ULS.

sec.title: Point 3. Crack density at the maximum allowable stress (σx = σmax)
sec.p: The distribution of crack density measurements at the maximum allowable stresses varies for each one of the laminates. The median and the scatter seem dependent on the probability that matrix cracking will start before the maximum allowable stress, and on the crack density at the ULS. For the [0/902]S, [0/904]S and [02/902]S laminates a crack density of at least 0.4 cracks/mm is very likely to be observed.

sec.title: Point 4. Stress at the ULS (ɛx = ɛu1T)
sec.p: The low probability values of the stresses at the ULS are very much dependent on the type of distribution utilized in the simulation. The simulations with the Weibull distributions show that, for all the laminates, the ULS has a probability of occurring higher than 10−5 at stresses lower or equal to the maximum allowable stresses; essentially for all the laminates the Pf > 10−5. On the other hand, the simulations with normal distributions show the opposite. In line with the discussion about the real distribution of ɛu1T mentioned before, it is reasonable to expect that the true stress that gives a Pf = 10−5 is somewhere between the predictions made with the probabilistic analyses with Weibull and normal distributions.

sec.title: Point 4. Crack density at the ULS (ɛx = ɛu1T)
sec.p: Similar to the stresses at the ULS, the low probability crack density values at the ULS are very much dependent on the type of distribution. One can observe that all the laminates are likely to present a reasonably high crack density (D > 0.6 cracks/mm) just before failure.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: From the comparison between the results of the deterministic and probabilistic analyses three important observations can be made. First, the probabilistic analyses show that the maximum allowable stresses for all the layups may, or may not, provide the target reliability level: a probability of failure of 10−5. This uncertainty arises from the fact that the prediction of a stress that would give such a safety level, through a probabilistic analysis, is very much dependent on the shape of the tail of the distribution used for the ɛu1T. This fact is clearly shown in the results of the probabilistic analyses, shown in Figure 6.

Second, the probabilistic analyses predict that at their maximum allowable stresses the [0/902]S, [0/904]S and [02/902]S laminates will most likely have a considerably high crack density. Matrix cracks degrade the mechanical properties of the laminate and act as a starting point for other types of damage, such as delamination. It would therefore be interesting to determine what would the maximum allowable crack density for a composite laminate be, so as to guarantee that the matrix cracks do not significantly contribute to the promotion of failure.

Third, the authors consider that the model used in this investigation is reasonably good at predicting the development of matrix cracks, see Figure 2, however the effect of their presence, beyond the reduction of laminate stiffness is not accounted for. High crack densities are considered to be likely to be observed close to the ULS point for all the layups. It would be reasonable to believe, that because of this high crack densities, the stresses that give a probability of failure of 10−5 calculated by means of the probabilistic analyses, are not in the conservative side, since such high crack densities would probably lead to failure occurring earlier than predicted.

Considering these observations, it is the authors’ opinion that the maximum allowable stresses, as determined by means of the deterministic analysis, did not provide the desired reliability level. Any further study aiming at motivating an increase in material utilization would need to provide answers regarding the tolerance of a laminate to matrix cracks, and the shape of the tail of the probability distributions used for the material properties, particularly the ones used in failure criteria.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The results of this study suggest that, for the studied cases the maximum allowable stresses, as determined by the deterministic linear elastic analysis with partial safety and model factors, do not provide the desired reliability; therefore, an increase of the maximum allowable stresses cannot be motivated. More importantly, the investigation shows that an increased understanding regarding the effects of matrix cracks, and therefore the maximum allowable crack density in a FRP laminate, would lead to safer FRP structures.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The authors acknowledge the support from the Lighthouse Maritime Competence Centre (www.lighthouse.nu), Sweden.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: This work was part of a deliverable by the authors to the EU-project BESST (www.besst.it). The authors thank John A. Nairn for his help with use of the variational fracture mechanics analysis.
